# 8.1 Modifying Traditional Games for Inclusive Physical Education ## Learning Objectives By the end of this session, you'll be able to: - Show how to change games so everyone can play - Work by yourself to make a game more fun and fair - Create a game that lets people with all kinds of skills join in ## Materials Needed - Soft ball or rolled-up socks - Tape or string for marking boundaries - Paper and pencil for recording scores and reflections - Container for a hoop (laundry basket, cardboard box, or large bowl) - 6-10 empty plastic bottles, toilet paper rolls, or cups for bowling pins - String and chairs to create a "net" - Balloon, beach ball, or wadded-up socks for volleyball - Household items for obstacle course (pillows, chairs, tables) - Timer (phone, watch, or clock) - Camera or phone for taking photos of game setup Not every traditional game works for all students right away. By making a few adjustments, we can transform games so everyone can participate, no matter their abilities. This lesson will help you understand how games work and ways to improve them for everyone. ## Warm-Up Activity 1. Grab a soft ball or roll up some socks to make one. 2. Toss it up and catch it 10 times with your dominant hand (the one you normally write with). 3. Now switch and catch with your non-dominant hand 10 times. 4. Record your results: How many successful catches did you make with each hand? **Reflection Task:** Write down 2-3 sentences about: - The difference in difficulty between your dominant and non-dominant hand - One specific adjustment you made to catch better with your non-dominant hand - How this experience relates to making games fair for people with different abilities This simple change shows how small modifications can completely transform how a game feels! ## Ways to Change Games Here are four main ways to make games more inclusive:
1. **Change the playing area size** - A smaller space helps if you move more slowly - Wider goals make scoring easier for everyone - Home setup: Use masking tape or string to mark boundaries in your available space - Example: Mark a 3'x3' square for a small target area or a 6'x6' area for more movement 2. **Simplify the rules** - Take out rules that confuse players - Add helpful rules like "everyone touches the ball before scoring" - Home setup: Write down 3-5 clear rules on a piece of paper and post it in your play area - Example: In catch, allowing the ball to bounce once before catching 3. **Use different equipment** - Swap in softer, lighter, or bigger balls - Lower targets so they're easier to hit - Home alternatives: - Beach ball → balloon or plastic grocery bag inflated with air - Basketball → rolled-up socks or soft stuffed toy - Net → string tied between two chairs - Cones → plastic cups or water bottles 4. **Change the number of players** - Create solo versions of team games - Design activities that work for one person - Home setup: Use walls for rebounding or set up targets to aim at - Example: Instead of competing against others, track your own scores and try to beat your personal best ## Adapting Traditional Games Now you'll become a game designer! Choose one of these games to modify: **Mini-Basketball** Setup instructions: 1. Find a container to use as your hoop (laundry basket, cardboard box, large bowl) 2. Place it against a wall or on a stable surface at a height that challenges you but isn't impossible 3. Measure and mark throwing lines at 3, 6, and 9 feet from the target using tape or objects 4. Create a ball from rolled-up socks, a small stuffed toy, or a soft rubber ball
Game instructions: 1. Take 10 shots from each distance line 2. Score 3 points for the farthest line, 2 for the middle, and 1 for the closest 3. Record your score after each round 4. Success criteria: Improve your total score over three rounds
Modifications to try: - Make the target larger or smaller - Add bonus targets worth extra points - Create a time challenge: How many baskets in 60 seconds? **Hallway Bowling** Setup instructions: 1. Collect 6-10 empty plastic bottles, toilet paper rolls, or cups 2. Arrange them in a triangle pattern at the end of a hallway or clear space 3. Mark throwing lines at different distances using tape or objects 4. Create a ball from rolled-up socks or use a soft rubber ball
Game instructions: 1. Roll your ball from behind the throwing line 2. Count how many pins you knock down 3. Set them up again and take a second roll 4. Add both scores together for your frame total 5. Play 5 frames and track your total score 6. Success criteria: Knock down at least 50% of pins across all frames
Modifications to try: - Change the width of the pin setup - Use heavier or lighter balls - Create zones worth different point values **Sock Volleyball** Setup instructions: 1. Create a "net" by tying string between two chairs or using the back of a couch 2. Mark your court with tape or objects on both sides of the net 3. Make a ball from a balloon, beach ball, or wadded-up socks 4. Set up a scoring system using paper and pencil
Game instructions: 1. Serve the ball by tossing it up and hitting it over the net 2. Let it bounce once on your side before returning it 3. Hit the ball back and forth, counting how many successful volleys you can make 4. For solo play: hit against a wall over a marked line 5. Success criteria: Complete 10 consecutive hits without missing
Modifications to try: - Allow multiple bounces - Use a larger or smaller ball - Change the height of the net **Indoor Obstacle Course** Setup instructions: 1. Identify 5-6 stations around your available space 2. Use household items that are stable and safe: pillows, chairs, tables, etc. 3. Create a map of your course with clear start and finish points 4. Set up a timer (phone, watch, or clock)
Game instructions: 1. Move through each station following specific movements: - Crawl under a table or chair - Step or jump over pillows - Balance walking along a line of tape - Zigzag around water bottles - Toss a sock ball into a container 2. Time yourself for three complete circuits 3. Record each time and calculate your average 4. Success criteria: Complete the course three times with consistent or improving times
Modifications to try: - Add or remove stations based on difficulty - Create different movement challenges at each station - Establish "challenge modes" with special rules ## Documentation and Reflection After creating your modified game:
Documentation tasks: 1. Take 3-5 photos of your game setup from different angles 2. Write down your complete set of rules (at least 5 points) 3. Create a simple scoring sheet to track your progress 4. List all the modifications you made to the original game
Reflection tasks (write 2-3 sentences for each): 1. Which specific change made the biggest improvement to your game and why? 2. Describe one modification that made your game more fair or accessible. 3. Explain how you would adjust your game to make it easier or harder. 4. How could you use these modification principles with friends who have different physical abilities? ## Conclusion Today you learned how to adapt familiar games to work better for everyone. By changing the playing space, simplifying rules, using different equipment, and adjusting how people play, you can create activities that include all players.
These skills matter in everyday life too. When you know how to modify activities so everyone can join in, you become a better friend and leader. Great games don't need fancy equipment or complicated rules—they just need to be fun and fair for everyone! **Final Task:** Create a "Game Modification Guide" by listing your favorite game and three specific modifications you could make to it. For each modification, explain: 1. What exactly you would change 2. What materials you would need 3. How this change makes the game more inclusive
Keep this guide for future reference when playing games with friends and family. ---keytakeaways--- ## Key Takeaways - Games can be made inclusive by modifying four key elements: playing area size, rules, equipment, and number of players. - Small adjustments to familiar games can create big improvements in accessibility, allowing everyone to participate regardless of their physical abilities. - Documenting your game modifications and reflecting on their effectiveness helps you develop skills for creating inclusive activities in any setting. ---keytakeawaysEND---
